title: Accepting last-minute moon witnesses
vignette: Two travelers rush in just before nightfall claiming they saw the new lunar cycle. The court already prepared to keep the next day as the 30th. Should their testimony be accepted?

options.text: Accept and declare the new month now.
Ignore them; maintain the preset schedule.

title: Horn Trumpet on Day of Rest
vignette: The first day of New Year observance falls on day of rest. Some communities blow the horn trumpet privately. May this be done?

options.text: No blowing on day of rest at all.
Blow discreetly so the moral obligation isn't missed.

title: Interrupting meditation for horn trumpet
vignette: During the silent prayer a horn trumpet blast is heard from outside. Should one pause to listen?

options.text: Pause briefly and listen.
Continue meditating without interruption.

title: Bent vs. straight horn trumpet
vignette: A community only has a straight antelope horn available. Traditionalists insist on a curved ram's horn. What should they do?

options.text: Use the available horn; fulfill the moral obligation.
Seek a curved horn even if it delays the service.

title: Women blowing horn trumpet
vignette: Several women want to blow horn trumpet themselves in community center. Some object that it is not obligatory for them.

options.text: Allow them; it inspires participation.
Discourage it; rely on the men's blasts.

title: Sending signal fires
vignette: The court debates whether to announce the new month by fires on mountain tops or by messengers only. Fires risk confusion from impostors.

options.text: Use fires for quick nationwide notice.
Rely solely on messengers to avoid mistakes.

title: False moon testimony
vignette: Witnesses are found to have lied about seeing the moon. Should they be punished publicly to deter others?

options.text: Yes; make an example of them.
No; quietly reject their testimony only.

title: Blowing horn trumpet for the king
vignette: A foreign monarch visiting the main city requests a special horn trumpet salute on New Year observance. Complying may show honour but also mix secular motives with the ritual.

options.text: Agree and blow as a gesture of respect.
Decline; the blasts are solely for worship.

title: Declaring the new month at night
vignette: Witnesses arrive after dark. Traditionally declaration of the new month is by day. May the court declare the new month that night?

options.text: Wait until morning despite the delay.
declare the new month immediately by torchlight.

title: Partial year as a full year
vignette: A king ascends the throne in a specific month. When counting reign years for contracts, is the coming another specific month already considered year two?

options.text: Yes; a partial year counts as a whole.
No; start counting only after twelve full months.

title: Changing the meditation order
vignette: The service leader wants to insert extra melodies between the horn trumpet blasts and their accompanying words of praise or request. Some object to altering tradition.

options.text: Allow creative melodies for inspiration.
Stick to the established order.

title: Children hearing horn trumpet
vignette: Young kids run around noisily during the horn trumpet service. Some wonder if it's worth bringing them at all since they don't listen attentively.

options.text: Bring them to accustom them early.
Leave them home to maintain decorum.

title: Minimum number of blasts
vignette: A small congregation only manages to blow a simple set of ten blasts instead of the usual series. Is the obligation fulfilled?

options.text: Yes; any coherent series suffices.
No; the full quota of blasts is required.

title: Traveling far to testify
vignette: Witnesses from a distant village will miss New Year observance at home if they travel to the main city to testify about the moon. Should they go?

options.text: Yes; made special status the calendar is paramount.
Stay home and celebrate locally.

title: Blowing horn trumpet after additional service
vignette: Some propose delaying the horn trumpet blasts until after the lengthy additional service to draw a bigger crowd. Others insist on blowing earlier.

options.text: Blow early during the service as usual.
Delay to maximise attendance.
